[He]179-tracy was jealous — and at the same time [he]179-tracy was not jealous . In a sense [the dead man]1522-the dead man was [himself]1522-the dead man ; in that case compliments and affection lavished upon that corpse went into [his]1522-the dead man own till and were clear profit . But in another sense [the dead man]1522-the dead man was not [himself]1522-the dead man ; and in that case all compliments and affection lavished there were wasted , and a sufficient basis for jealousy . A tiff was the result of the dispute between [the two]2047-the two . Then [they]2047-the two made it up , and were more loving than ever . As [an affectionate clincher of the reconciliation]1525-an affectionate clincher of the reconciliation , [Sally]144-gwendolen declared that [she]144-gwendolen had now banished [Lord Berkeley]166-lord berkeley from [her]144-gwendolen mind ; and added , “ And in order to make sure that [he]166-lord berkeley shall never make trouble between [us]2047-the two again , [I]179-tracy will teach [myself]179-tracy to detest that name and all that have ever borne it or ever shall bear it . ”[179-tracy] This inflicted another pang , and [Tracy]179-tracy was minded to ask [her]144-gwendolen to modify that a little just on general principles , and as practice in not overdoing a good thing — perhaps [he]179-tracy might better leave things as they were and not risk bringing on another tiff . [He]179-tracy got away from that particular , and sought less tender ground for conversation . “ [I]179-tracy suppose [you]144-gwendolen disapprove wholly of aristocracies and nobilities , now that [you]144-gwendolen have renounced [your]144-gwendolen title and [[your]144-gwendolen father]2446-your father ’s earldom . ”[179-tracy] “ _ [Real _ ones]3120-real _ ones ? Oh , dear no — but [I]1531-the shady devil ’ve thrown aside [our]3121-our sham one for good . ”[1531-the shady devil] This answer fell just at the right time and just in the right place , to save [the poor unstable young man]1526-the poor unstable young man from changing [his]1526-the poor unstable young man political complexion once more . [He]1526-the poor unstable young man had been on the point of beginning to totter again , but this prop shored [him]1526-the poor unstable young man up and kept [him]1526-the poor unstable young man from floundering back into democracy and re - renouncing aristocracy . So [he]1526-the poor unstable young man went [home]1782-home glad that [he]1526-the poor unstable young man had asked the fortunate question . [The girl]953-the girl would accept a little thing like a genuine earldom , [she]953-the girl was merely prejudiced against the brummagem article . Yes , [he]1526-the poor unstable young man could have [[his]1526-the poor unstable young man girl]1529-his girl and have [his]1526-the poor unstable young man earldom , too : that question was a fortunate stroke . [Sally]144-gwendolen went to bed happy , too ; and remained happy , deliriously happy , for nearly two hours ; but at last , just as [she]144-gwendolen was sinking into a contented and luxurious unconsciousness , [the shady devil who lives and lurks and hides and watches inside of human beings]1530-the shady devil who lives and lurks and hides and watches inside of human beings and is always waiting for a chance to do the proprietor a malicious damage , whispered to [her]144-gwendolen soul and said , “ That question had a harmless look , but what was _ back _ of it?—what was the secret motive of it?—what suggested it ? ”[144-gwendolen] [The shady devil]1531-the shady devil had knifed [her]144-gwendolen , and could retire , now , and take a rest ; the wound would attend to business for [him]1526-the poor unstable young man . And it did . p234.jpg ( 24 K ) _ Why _ should [Howard Tracy]179-tracy ask that question ? If [he]1526-the poor unstable young man was not trying to marry [her]144-gwendolen for the sake of [her]144-gwendolen rank , what should suggest that question to [him]1526-the poor unstable young man ? Did n’t [he]1526-the poor unstable young man plainly look gratified when [she]144-gwendolen said [her]144-gwendolen objections to aristocracy had their limitations ? Ah , [he]1526-the poor unstable young man is after that earldom , that gilded sham — it is n’t poor [me]0-i [he]1526-the poor unstable young man wants . So [she]144-gwendolen argued , in anguish and tears . Then [she]144-gwendolen argued the opposite theory , but made a weak , poor business of it , and lost the case . [She]144-gwendolen kept the arguing up , one side and then the other , the rest of the night , and at last fell asleep at dawn ; fell in the fire at dawn , [one]372-one may say ; for that kind of sleep resembles fire , and [one]372-one comes out of it with [his]372-one brain baked and [his]372-one physical forces fried out of [him]372-one . CHAPTER XXIII . [Tracy]179-tracy wrote [[his]179-tracy father]302-his father before [he]179-tracy sought [his]179-tracy bed . [He]1526-the poor unstable young man wrote a letter which [he]1526-the poor unstable young man believed would get better treatment than [his]1526-the poor unstable young man cablegram received , for it contained what ought to be welcome news ; namely , that [he]1526-the poor unstable young man had tried equality and working for a living ; had made a fight which [he]1526-the poor unstable young man could find no reason to be ashamed of , and in the matter of earning a living had proved that [he]1526-the poor unstable young man was able to do it ; but that on the whole [he]1526-the poor unstable young man had arrived at the conclusion that [he]1526-the poor unstable young man could not reform [the world]409-the world single - handed , and was willing to retire from the conflict with the fair degree of honor which [he]1526-the poor unstable young man had gained , and was also willing to return [home]1782-home and resume [his]1526-the poor unstable young man position and be content with it and thankful for it for the future , leaving further experiment of a missionary sort to [other young people needing the chastening and quelling persuasions of experience]1537-other young people needing the chastening and quelling persuasions of experience , the only logic sure to convince a diseased imagination and restore it to rugged health . Then [he]1526-the poor unstable young man approached the subject of marriage with [the daughter of [the American Claimant]661-the american claimant]1538-the daughter of the american claimant with a good deal of caution and much painstaking art . [He]1526-the poor unstable young man said praiseful and appreciative things about [the girl]953-the girl , but did n’t dwell upon that detail or make it prominent . The thing which [he]1526-the poor unstable young man made prominent was the opportunity now so happily afforded , to reconcile [York]80-york and [Lancaster]81-lancaster , graft the warring roses upon one stem , and end forever a crying injustice which had already lasted far too long . [One]372-one could infer that [he]1526-the poor unstable young man had thought this thing all out and chosen this way of making all things fair and right because it was sufficiently fair and considerably wiser than the renunciation - scheme which [he]1526-the poor unstable young man had brought with [him]1526-the poor unstable young man from [England]11-england . [One]372-one could infer that , but [he]1526-the poor unstable young man did n’t say it . In fact the more [he]1526-the poor unstable young man read [his]1526-the poor unstable young man letter over , the more [he]1526-the poor unstable young man got to inferring it [himself]1526-the poor unstable young man . When [the old earl]1296-the old earl received that letter , the first part of it filled [him]1526-the poor unstable young man with a grim and snarly satisfaction ; but the rest of it brought a snort or two out of [him]1526-the poor unstable young man that could be translated differently . [He]1526-the poor unstable young man wasted no ink in this emergency , either in cablegrams or letters ; [he]1526-the poor unstable young man promptly took [ship]2783-ship for [America]9-america to look into the matter [himself]1526-the poor unstable young man . [He]1526-the poor unstable young man had staunchly held [his]1526-the poor unstable young man grip all this long time , and given no sign of the hunger at [his]1526-the poor unstable young man heart to see [[his]1526-the poor unstable young man son]337-his son ; hoping for the cure of [his]1526-the poor unstable young man insane dream , and resolute that the process should go through all the necessary stages without assuaging telegrams or other nonsense from [home]1782-home , and here was victory at last . Victory , but stupidly marred by this idiotic marriage project . Yes , [he]1526-the poor unstable young man would step over and take a hand in this matter [himself]1526-the poor unstable young man . During the first ten days following the mailing of the letter [Tracy]179-tracy ’s spirits had no idle time ; [they]1547-they were always climbing up into the clouds or sliding down into [the earth]1900-the earth as deep as the law of gravitation reached . [He]179-tracy was intensely happy or intensely miserable by turns , according to [Miss Sally]234-miss sally ’s moods . [He]179-tracy never could tell when the mood was going to change , and when it changed [he]179-tracy could n’t tell what it was that had changed it . Sometimes [she]234-miss sally was so in love with [him]179-tracy that [her]234-miss sally love was tropical , torrid , and [she]234-miss sally could find no language fervent enough for its expression ; then suddenly , and without warning or any apparent reason , the weather would change , and [the victim]1234-the victim would find [himself]1234-the victim adrift among the icebergs and feeling as lonesome and friendless as [the north pole]1550-the north pole . It sometimes seemed to [him]179-tracy that [a man]1806-a man might better be dead than exposed to these devastating varieties of climate . The case was simple . [Sally]234-miss sally _ wanted _ to believe that [Tracy]179-tracy ’s preference was disinterested ; so [she]234-miss sally was always applying little tests of one sort or another , hoping and expecting that [they]1552-they would bring out evidence which would confirm or fortify [her]234-miss sally belief . [Poor Tracy]179-tracy did not know that these experiments were being made upon [him]179-tracy , consequently [he]179-tracy walked promptly into all the traps [the girl]953-the girl set for [him]179-tracy . These traps consisted in apparently casual references to social distinction , aristocratic title and privilege , and such things . Often [Tracy]179-tracy responded to these references heedlessly and not much caring what [he]179-tracy said provided it kept the talk going and prolonged the seance . [He]179-tracy did n’t suspect that [the girl]953-the girl was watching [his]179-tracy face and listening for [his]179-tracy words as [one who watches [the judge]1556-the judge ’s face and listens for the words which will restore [him]179-tracy to [home]1782-home and [friends]325-friends and freedom or shut [him]179-tracy away from the sun and human companionship forever]1555-one who watches the judge ’s face and listens for the words which will restore him to home and friends and freedom or shut him away from the sun and human companionship forever . [He]179-tracy did n’t suspect that [his]179-tracy careless words were being weighed , and so [he]179-tracy often delivered sentence of death when it would have been just as handy and all the same to [him]179-tracy to pronounce acquittal . Daily [he]179-tracy broke [the girl]953-the girl ’s heart , nightly [he]179-tracy sent [her]953-the girl to the rack for sleep . [He]179-tracy could n’t understand it . [Some people]1560-some people would have put this and that together and perceived that the weather never changed until one particular subject was introduced , and that then it _ always _ changed . And [they]1560-some people would have looked further , and perceived that that subject was always introduced by [the one party]1561-the one party , never [the other]808-the other . [They]1560-some people would have argued , then , that this was done for a purpose . If [they]1560-some people could not find out what that purpose was in any simpler or easier way , [they]1560-some people would _ ask _ . But [Tracy]179-tracy was not deep enough or suspicious enough to think of these things . [He]179-tracy noticed only one particular ; that the weather was always sunny when a visit _ began _ . No matter how much it might cloud up later , it always began with a clear sky . [He]179-tracy could n’t explain this curious fact to [himself]179-tracy , [he]179-tracy merely knew it to be a fact . The truth of the matter was , that by the time [Tracy]179-tracy had been out of [Sally]234-miss sally ’s sight six hours [she]953-the girl was so famishing for a sight of [him]179-tracy that [her]953-the girl doubts and suspicions were all consumed away in the fire of that longing , and so always [she]953-the girl came into [his]179-tracy presence as surprisingly radiant and joyous as [she]953-the girl was n’t when [she]953-the girl went out of it . In circumstances like these a growing portrait runs a good many risks . The portrait of [Sellers]144-gwendolen , by [Tracy]179-tracy , was fighting along , day by day , through this mixed weather , and daily adding to itself ineradicable signs of the checkered life it was leading . It was the happiest portrait , in spots , that was ever seen ; but in other spots [a damned soul]1563-a damned soul looked out from it ; [a soul that was suffering all the different kinds of distress there are , from stomach ache to rabies]1564-a soul that was suffering all the different kinds of distress there are , from stomach ache to rabies . But [Sellers]144-gwendolen liked it . [He]179-tracy said it was just [himself]179-tracy all over — a portrait that sweated moods from every pore , and [no two moods alike]1565-no two moods alike . [He]179-tracy said [he]179-tracy had as many different kinds of emotions in [him]179-tracy as [a jug]1566-a jug . It was a kind of a deadly work of art , maybe , but it was a starchy picture for show ; for it was life size , full length , and represented [the American earl]1567-the american earl in [a peer]1568-a peer ’s scarlet robe , with the three ermine bars indicative of [an earl]1125-an earl ’s rank , and on the gray head [an earl]1125-an earl ’s coronet , tilted just a wee bit to one side in a most gallus and winsome way . When [Sally]144-gwendolen ’s weather was sunny the portrait made [Tracy]179-tracy chuckle , but when [her]144-gwendolen weather was overcast it disordered [his]179-tracy mind and stopped the circulation of [his]179-tracy blood . Late one night when [the sweethearts]1571-the sweethearts had been having a flawless visit together , [Sally]144-gwendolen ’s interior devil began to work [his]179-tracy specialty , and soon the conversation was drifting toward the customary rock . Presently , in the midst of [Tracy]179-tracy ’s serene flow of talk , [he]179-tracy felt a shudder which [he]179-tracy knew was not [his]179-tracy shudder , but exterior to [his]179-tracy breast although immediately against it . After the shudder came sobs ; [Sally]144-gwendolen was crying . “ Oh , [[my]144-gwendolen darling]561-my darling , what have [I]144-gwendolen done — what have [I]144-gwendolen said ? It has happened again ! Oh , what _ did _ possess [him]1582-he to think [he]1582-he could succeed as [a fraud]3163-a fraud — and [he]1582-he has n’t the first requisite except duplicity that [I]114-hawkins can see . Oh , dear , [I]114-hawkins ’ll go to bed and give it all up . Oh , [I]114-hawkins _ wish _ [I]114-hawkins had told [him]1582-he to come and tell [me]114-hawkins whenever [he]1582-he did n’t get any telegram — and now it ’s all [my]114-hawkins own fault if [I]114-hawkins never see [him]1582-he again . How [my]114-hawkins eyes must look ! ”[114-hawkins] CHAPTER XXIV . Next day , sure enough , the cablegram did n’t come . This was an immense disaster ; for [Tracy]179-tracy could n’t go into the presence without that ticket , although it was n’t going to possess any value as evidence . But if the failure of the cablegram on that first day may be called an immense disaster , where is the dictionary that can turn out a phrase sizeable enough to describe the tenth day ’s failure ? Of course every day that the cablegram did n’t come made [Tracy]179-tracy all of twenty - four hours ’ more ashamed of [himself]179-tracy than [he]179-tracy was the day before , and made [Sally]144-gwendolen fully twenty - four hours more certain than ever that [he]179-tracy not only had n’t [any father]1584-any father anywhere , but had n’t even [a confederate]1585-a confederate — and so it followed that [he]179-tracy was [a double - dyed humbug]1586-a double - dyed humbug and could n’t be otherwise . These were hard days for [Barrow]191-barrow and [the art firm]1587-the art firm . All these had [their]1588-their hands full , trying to comfort [Tracy]179-tracy . [Barrow]191-barrow ’s task was particularly hard , because [he]191-barrow was made [a confidant in full]1589-a confidant in full , and therefore had to humor [Tracy]179-tracy ’s delusion that [he]179-tracy had [a father]2641-a father , and that [the father]303-the father was [an earl]1125-an earl , and that [he]179-tracy was going to send a cablegram . [Barrow]191-barrow early gave up the idea of trying to convince [Tracy]179-tracy that [he]179-tracy had n’t [any father]1584-any father , because this had such a bad effect on [the patient]1594-the patient , and worked up [his]191-barrow temper to such an alarming degree . [He]191-barrow had tried , as an experiment , letting [Tracy]179-tracy think [he]179-tracy had [a father]2641-a father ; the result was so good that [he]191-barrow went further , with proper caution , and tried letting [him]179-tracy think [[his]179-tracy father]302-his father was [an earl]1125-an earl ; this wrought so well , that [he]191-barrow grew bold , and tried letting [him]179-tracy think [he]179-tracy had [two fathers]1598-two fathers , if [he]179-tracy wanted to , but [he]179-tracy did n’t want to , so [Barrow]191-barrow withdrew one of [them]1598-two fathers and substituted letting [him]179-tracy think [he]179-tracy was going to get a cablegram — which [Barrow]191-barrow judged [he]179-tracy would n’t , and was right ; but [Barrow]191-barrow worked the cablegram daily for all it was worth , and it was the one thing that kept [Tracy]179-tracy alive ; that was [Barrow]191-barrow ’s opinion . And these were bitter hard days for poor [Sally]144-gwendolen , and mainly delivered up to private crying . [She]144-gwendolen kept [her]144-gwendolen furniture pretty damp , and so caught cold , and the dampness and the cold and the sorrow together undermined [her]144-gwendolen appetite , and [she]144-gwendolen was a pitiful enough object , poor thing . [Her]144-gwendolen state was bad enough , as per statement of it above quoted ; but all the forces of nature and circumstance seemed conspiring to make it worse — and succeeding . For instance , the morning after [her]144-gwendolen dismissal of [Tracy]179-tracy , [Hawkins]114-hawkins and [Sellers]144-gwendolen read in the associated press dispatches that a toy puzzle called Pigs in [the Clover]35-the clover , had come into sudden favor within the past few weeks , and that from [the Atlantic]66-the atlantic to the Pacific [all the populations of [all the States]1600-all the states]1599-all the populations of all the states had knocked off work to play with it , and that the business of [the country]1904-the country had now come to a standstill by consequence ; that [judges]1602-judges , [lawyers]1603-lawyers , [burglars]1604-burglars , [parsons]1605-parsons , [thieves]1606-thieves , [merchants]1607-merchants , [mechanics]2332-mechanics , [murderers]1609-murderers , [women]2131-women , [children]2132-children , [babies]1612-babies — [everybody]404-everybody , indeed , could be seen from morning till midnight , absorbed in one deep project and purpose , and only one — to pen those pigs , work out that puzzle successfully ; that all gayety , all cheerfulness had departed from [the nation]836-the nation , and in [its]836-the nation place care , preoccupation and anxiety sat upon every countenance , and all faces were drawn , distressed , and furrowed with the signs of age and trouble , and marked with the still sadder signs of mental decay and incipient madness ; that [factories]1615-factories were at work night and day in [eight cities]1616-eight cities , and yet to supply the demand for the puzzle was thus far impossible . [Hawkins]114-hawkins was wild with joy , but [Sellers]144-gwendolen was calm . Small matters could not disturb [his]114-hawkins serenity . [He]114-hawkins said — “ That ’s just the way things go . [A man]1806-a man invents a thing which could revolutionize the arts , produce mountains of money , and bless [the earth]1900-the earth , and who will bother with it or show any interest in it?—and so [you]3166-you are just as poor as [you]3166-you were before . But [you]3166-you invent some worthless thing to amuse [yourself]3166-you with , and would throw it away if let alone , and all of a sudden [the whole world]2837-the whole world makes a snatch for it and out crops a fortune . Hunt up [that Yankee]3168-that yankee and collect , [Hawkins]114-hawkins — half is [yours]114-hawkins , [you]114-hawkins know . Leave [me]336-the old gentleman to potter at [my]336-the old gentleman lecture . ”[336-the old gentleman] This was a temperance lecture . [Sellers]144-gwendolen was [head chief in [the Temperance camp]1618-the temperance camp]1617-head chief in the temperance camp , and had lectured , now and then in that interest , but had been dissatisfied with [his]114-hawkins efforts ; wherefore [he]114-hawkins was now about to try a new plan . After much thought [he]114-hawkins had concluded that a main reason why [his]114-hawkins lectures lacked fire or something , was that they were too transparently amateurish ; that is to say , it was probably too plainly perceptible that [the lecturer]1619-the lecturer was trying to tell [people]1954-people about the horrid effects of liquor when [he]114-hawkins did n’t really know anything about those effects except from hearsay , since [he]114-hawkins had hardly ever tasted an intoxicant in [his]114-hawkins life . [His]114-hawkins scheme , now , was to prepare [himself]114-hawkins to speak from bitter experience . [Hawkins]114-hawkins was to stand by with the bottle , calculate the doses , watch the effects , make notes of results , and otherwise assist in the preparation . Time was short , for [the ladies]705-the ladies would be along about noon — that is to say , [the temperance organization called [the Daughters of [Siloam]82-siloam]1623-the daughters of siloam]1622-the temperance organization called the daughters of siloam — and [Sellers]144-gwendolen must be ready to head [the procession]1624-the procession . The time kept slipping along — [Hawkins]114-hawkins did not return — [Sellers]144-gwendolen could not venture to wait longer ; so [he]114-hawkins attacked the bottle [himself]114-hawkins , and proceeded to note the effects . [Hawkins]114-hawkins got back at last ; took one comprehensive glance at [the lecturer]1619-the lecturer , and went down and headed off [the procession]1624-the procession . [The ladies]705-the ladies were grieved to hear that [the champion]1628-the champion had been taken suddenly ill and violently so , but glad to hear that it was hoped [he]1628-the champion would be out again in a few days . As it turned out , [the old gentleman]336-the old gentleman did n’t turn over or show any signs of life worth speaking of for twenty - four hours . Then [he]336-the old gentleman asked after the procession , and learned what had happened about it . [He]336-the old gentleman was sorry ; said [he]336-the old gentleman had been “ fixed ”[336-the old gentleman] for it . [He]336-the old gentleman remained abed several days , and [[his]336-the old gentleman wife]381-his wife and [daughter]2144-daughter took turns in sitting with [him]336-the old gentleman and ministering to [his]336-the old gentleman wants . Often [he]336-the old gentleman patted [Sally]144-gwendolen ’s head and tried to comfort [her]144-gwendolen . “ Do n’t cry , [[my]2008-the mother child]2231-my child , do n’t cry so ; _ [you]2231-my child _ know [[your]2231-my child old father]3170-your old father did it by mistake and did n’t mean a bit of harm ; [you]2231-my child know [he]336-the old gentleman would n’t intentionally do anything to make [you]2231-my child ashamed for [the world]409-the world ; [you]2231-my child know [he]336-the old gentleman was trying to do good and only made the mistake through ignorance , not knowing the right doses and [Washington]114-hawkins not there to help . Do n’t cry so , [dear]1855-dear , it breaks [my]2008-the mother old heart to see [you]1855-dear , and think [I]2008-the mother ’ve brought this humiliation on [you]1855-dear and [you]1855-dear so dear to [me]2008-the mother and so good . [I]2008-the mother wo n’t ever do it again , indeed [I]2008-the mother wo n’t ; now be comforted , [honey]2152-honey , that ’s [a good child]3174-a good child . ”[2008-the mother] But when [she]1632-she was n’t on duty at the bedside the crying went on just the same ; then [the mother]2008-the mother would try to comfort [her]1632-she , and say : “ Do n’t cry , [dear]1855-dear , _ [he]336-the old gentleman _ never meant any harm ; it was all one of those happens that [you]2231-my child ca n’t guard against when [you]2231-my child are trying experiments , that way . [You]2231-my child see _ [I]144-gwendolen _ do n’t cry . It ’s because [I]144-gwendolen know [him]336-the old gentleman so well . [I]144-gwendolen could never look [anybody]1915-anybody in the face again if [he]336-the old gentleman had got into such an amazing condition as that a - purpose ; but bless [you]2231-my child [his]336-the old gentleman intention was pure and high , and that makes the _ act _ pure , though it was higher than was necessary . [We]3177-we ’re not humiliated , [dear]1855-dear , [he]336-the old gentleman did it under a noble impulse and [we]3177-we do n’t need to be ashamed . There , do n’t cry any more , [honey]2152-honey . ”[144-gwendolen] Thus , [the old gentleman]336-the old gentleman was useful to [Sally]144-gwendolen , during several days , as an explanation of [her]144-gwendolen tearfulness . [She]144-gwendolen felt thankful to [him]336-the old gentleman for the shelter [he]336-the old gentleman was affording [her]144-gwendolen , but often said to [herself]144-gwendolen , “ It ’s a shame to let [him]336-the old gentleman see in [my]336-the old gentleman crying a reproach — as if [he]336-the old gentleman could ever do anything that could make [me]336-the old gentleman reproach [him]336-the old gentleman ! But [I]336-the old gentleman ca n’t confess ; [I]336-the old gentleman ’ve got to go on using [him]336-the old gentleman for a pretext , [he]336-the old gentleman ’s [the only one [I]336-the old gentleman ’ve got in [the world]409-the world]3180-the only one i ’ve got in the world , and [I]336-the old gentleman do need one so much . ”[336-the old gentleman] As soon as [Sellers]144-gwendolen was out again , and found that stacks of money had been placed in bank for [him]336-the old gentleman and [Hawkins]114-hawkins by [the Yankee]1635-the yankee , [he]336-the old gentleman said , “ _ Now _ [we]3182-we ’ll soon see who ’s [the Claimant]3183-the claimant and who ’s [the Authentic]3184-the authentic . [I]144-gwendolen ’ll just go over there and warm up [that House of Lords]3185-that house of lords . ”[144-gwendolen] During the next few days [he]336-the old gentleman and [[his]336-the old gentleman wife]381-his wife were so busy with preparations for the voyage that [Sally]144-gwendolen had all the privacy [she]144-gwendolen needed , and all the chance to cry that was good for [her]144-gwendolen . Then [the old pair]1637-the old pair left for [New York]36-new york — and [England]11-england . [Sally]144-gwendolen had also had a chance to do another thing . That was , to make up [her]144-gwendolen mind that life was not worth living upon the present terms . If [she]144-gwendolen _ must _ give up [her]144-gwendolen impostor and die , doubtless [she]144-gwendolen must submit ; but might [she]144-gwendolen not lay [her]144-gwendolen whole case before [some disinterested person]1638-some disinterested person , first , and see if there was n’t perhaps some saving way out of the matter ? [She]144-gwendolen turned this idea over in [her]144-gwendolen mind a good deal . In [her]144-gwendolen first visit with [Hawkins]114-hawkins after [[her]144-gwendolen parents]1639-her parents were gone , the talk fell upon [Tracy]179-tracy , and [she]144-gwendolen was impelled to set [her]144-gwendolen case before [the statesman]1640-the statesman and take [his]1640-the statesman counsel . So [she]144-gwendolen poured out [her]144-gwendolen heart , and [he]1640-the statesman listened with painful solicitude . [She]144-gwendolen concluded , pleadingly , with — “ _ Do n’t _ tell [me]1641-the poor man [he]1640-the statesman is [an impostor]3186-an impostor . [I]1641-the poor man suppose [he]1640-the statesman is , but does n’t it look to [you]1640-the statesman as if [he]1640-the statesman is n’t ? [You]1640-the statesman are cool , [you]1640-the statesman know , and outside ; and so , maybe it can look to [you]1640-the statesman as if [he]1640-the statesman is n’t one , when it ca n’t to [me]1641-the poor man . _ Does n’t _ it look to [you]1640-the statesman as if [he]1640-the statesman is n’t ? Could n’t you—_can’t _ it look to [you]1640-the statesman that way — for — for [my]1641-the poor man sake ? ”[1641-the poor man] [The poor man]1641-the poor man was troubled , but [he]1641-the poor man felt obliged to keep in the neighborhood of the truth . [He]1641-the poor man fought around the present detail a little while , then gave it up and said [he]1641-the poor man could n’t really see [his]1641-the poor man way to clearing [Tracy]179-tracy . “ No , ”[1641-the poor man] [he]1641-the poor man said , “ the truth is , [he]1640-the statesman ’s [an impostor]3186-an impostor . ”[1641-the poor man] “ That is , [you]1640-the statesman — [you]1640-the statesman feel a little certain , but not entirely — oh , not _ entirely _ , [Mr. Hawkins]250-hawkins ! ”[1641-the poor man] “ It ’s a pity to have to say it — [I]1641-the poor man do hate to say it , but [I]1641-the poor man do n’t think anything about it , [I]1641-the poor man know [he]1640-the statesman ’s [an impostor]3186-an impostor . ”[1641-the poor man] “ Oh , now , [Mr. Hawkins]250-hawkins , [you]250-hawkins _ ca n’t _ go that far . Yes — at least the most of it — it ought to be done . So [he]1641-the poor man set [his]1641-the poor man teeth and went at the matter with determination , but purposing to spare [the girl]953-the girl one pain — that of knowing that [Tracy]179-tracy was [a criminal]1643-a criminal . “ Now [I]953-the girl am going to tell [you]250-hawkins a plain tale ; one not pleasant for [me]953-the girl to tell or for [you]250-hawkins to hear , but [we]3189-we ’ve got to stand it . [He]250-hawkins said : “ [I]953-the girl do n’t know that [I]953-the girl quite understand . [He]3190-that fellow is [the whole world]2837-the whole world to [me]1645-i , just as [he]3190-that fellow is ; [he]3190-that fellow comprehends _ all _ the values there are — then how can [you]250-hawkins _ add _ one ? ”[1645-i] “ [She]3190-that fellow ’s pretty far gone . ”[1645-i] [He]1645-i said that to [himself]1645-i . [[His]1828-this one brother]324-his brother , [Zylobalsamum]84-zylobalsamum — ”[1647-i] “ Wait — give [me]1647-i a chance to realize that . It is perfectly stupefying . Is it a disease ? ”[1647-i] “ No , [I]1647-i do n’t think it ’s a disease . It ’s either Scriptural or — ”[1647-i] “ Well , it ’s not Scriptural . ”[1647-i] “ Then it ’s anatomical . [I]1647-i knew it was one or the other . Yes , [I]1647-i remember , now , it _ is _ anatomical . It ’s a ganglion — a nerve centre — it is what is called the zylobalsamum process . ”[1647-i] “ Well , go on ; and if [you]1647-i come to any more of [them]486-idiots , omit the names ; they make [one]372-one feel so uncomfortable . ”[1647-i] “ Very well , then . As [I]1647-i said , [this one]1828-this one was not a favorite in [the family]1868-the family , and so [he]1828-this one was neglected in every way , never sent to [school]3229-school , always allowed to associate with [the worst and coarsest characters]3230-the worst and coarsest characters , and so of course [he]1828-this one has grown up [a rude , vulgar , ignorant , dissipated ruffian]3231-a rude , vulgar , ignorant , dissipated ruffian , and — ”[1647-i] “ [He]1828-this one ? [You]1647-i ought to be more generous than to make such a statement as that about [a poor young stranger who — who — why , [he]1828-this one is the very opposite of that]3232-a poor young stranger who — who — why , he is the very opposite of that ! [He]1828-this one is considerate , courteous , obliging , modest , gentle , refined , cultivated—_oh _ , for shame ! how can [you]1647-i say such things about [him]1828-this one ? ”[1647-i] “ [I]1647-i do n’t blame [you]1647-i , [Sally]144-gwendolen — indeed [I]1647-i have n’t a word of blame for [you]1647-i for being blinded by — [your]1647-i affection — blinded to these minor defects which are so manifest to others who — ”[1647-i] “ Minor defects ? Do [you]1647-i call these minor defects ? What are murder and arson , pray ? ”[1647-i] “ It is a difficult question to answer straight off — and of course estimates of such things vary with environment . With [us]3233-us , out [our]3233-us way , [they]3234-they would not necessarily attract as much attention as with [you]1647-i , yet [they]3234-they are often regarded with disapproval — ”[1647-i] “ Murder and arson are regarded with disapproval ? ”[1647-i] “ Oh , frequently . ”[1647-i] “ With disapproval . [I]1647-i _ knew _ [that family]3237-that family — personally . ”[1647-i] This was a surprise . “ [You]1647-i ? [Meantime Sally]254-sally had thought [her]144-gwendolen case out and made up [her]144-gwendolen mind . CHAPTER XXV . [Hawkins]250-hawkins went straight to [the telegraph office]2628-the telegraph office and disburdened [his]250-hawkins conscience . [He]250-hawkins said to [himself]250-hawkins , “ [She]3257-she ’s not going to give [this galvanized cadaver]3258-this galvanized cadaver up , that ’s plain . [She]3257-she ’s going to marry [the materializee _]3260-the materializee _ . ”[144-gwendolen] Meantime a note came to [Rossmore Towers]46-rossmore towers to say that [the Earl of Rossmore]110-rossmore had just arrived from [England]11-england , and would do [himself]110-rossmore the pleasure of calling in the evening . As it was , [he]179-tracy was too miserable to wait any longer ; for [his]179-tracy last hope — a letter — had failed [him]179-tracy . It was fully due to - day ; it had not come . Had [[his]179-tracy father]302-his father really flung [him]179-tracy away ? It looked so . It was not like [[his]179-tracy father]302-his father , but it surely looked so . [[His]179-tracy father]302-his father was [a rather tough nut]1655-a rather tough nut , in truth , but had never been so with [[his]302-his father son]337-his son — still , this implacable silence had a calamitous look . Anyway , [Tracy]179-tracy would go to [the Towers]1292-the towers and — then what ? [He]179-tracy did n’t know ; [his]179-tracy head was tired out with thinking — [he]179-tracy would n’t think about what [he]179-tracy must do or say — let it all take care of itself . So that [he]179-tracy saw [Sally]144-gwendolen once more , [he]179-tracy would be satisfied , happen what might ; [he]179-tracy would n’t care . [He]179-tracy hardly knew how [he]179-tracy got to [the Towers]1292-the towers , or when . [He]179-tracy knew and cared for only one thing — [he]179-tracy was alone with [Sally]144-gwendolen . [She]144-gwendolen was kind , [she]144-gwendolen was gentle , there was moisture in [her]144-gwendolen eyes , and a yearning something in [her]144-gwendolen face and manner which [she]144-gwendolen could not wholly hide — but [she]144-gwendolen kept [her]144-gwendolen distance . [They]1659-they talked . [I]144-gwendolen try to read , but [I]144-gwendolen ca n’t seem to get interested in any book . [I]144-gwendolen try the newspapers , but [they]3264-they do put such rubbish in them . [Hawkins]257-hawkins was going as far as [New York]36-new york with [the party]1697-the party , and said [he]257-hawkins would explain the matter on [the road]695-the road . The explanation was in a letter left by [the colonel]374-the colonel in [Hawkins]257-hawkins ’s hands . In it [he]257-hawkins promised to join [Mrs. Sellers]98-mrs. sellers later , in [England]11-england , and then went on to say : The truth is , [[my]0-i dear]605-my dear [Hawkins]257-hawkins , a mighty idea has been born to [me]0-i within the hour , and [I]0-i must not even stop to say goodbye to [[my]0-i dear ones]1701-my dear ones . [A man]1806-a man ’s highest duty takes precedence of [all minor ones]1703-all minor ones , and must be attended to with [his]1806-a man best promptness and energy , at whatsoever cost to [his]1806-a man affections or [his]1806-a man convenience . And first of all [a man]1806-a man ’s duties is [his]1806-a man duty to [his]1806-a man own honor — [he]1806-a man must keep that spotless . [Mine]98-mrs. sellers is threatened . When [I]0-i was feeling sure of [my]0-i imminent future solidity , [I]0-i forwarded to [the Czar of [Russia]30-russia]1705-the czar of russia — perhaps prematurely — an offer for the purchase of [Siberia]17-siberia , naming a vast sum . Since then an episode has warned [me]0-i that the method by which [I]0-i was expecting to acquire this money — materialization upon a scale of limitless magnitude — is marred by a taint of temporary uncertainty . [[His]1705-the czar of russia imperial majesty]1706-his imperial majesty may accept [my]0-i offer at any moment . If this should occur now , [I]0-i should find [myself]0-i painfully embarrassed , in fact financially inadequate . [I]0-i could not take [Siberia]17-siberia . This would become known , and [my]0-i credit would suffer . Recently [my]0-i private hours have been dark indeed , but the sun shines again now ; [I]0-i see [my]0-i way ; [I]0-i shall be able to meet [my]0-i obligation , and without having to ask an extension of the stipulated time , [I]0-i think . This grand new idea of [mine]0-i — the sublimest [I]0-i have ever conceived , will save [me]0-i whole , [I]0-i am sure . [I]0-i am leaving for [San Francisco]59-san francisco this moment , to test it , by the help of the great Lick telescope . Like all of [my]0-i more notable discoveries and inventions , it is based upon hard , practical scientific laws ; all other bases are unsound and hence untrustworthy . In brief , then , [I]0-i have conceived the stupendous idea of reorganizing the climates of [the earth]1900-the earth according to the desire of [the populations interested]1708-the populations interested . That is to say , [I]0-i will furnish climates to order , for cash or negotiable paper , taking the old climates in part payment , of course , at a fair discount , where they are in condition to be repaired at small cost and let out for hire to poor and remote communities not able to afford a good climate and not caring for an expensive one for mere display . [My]0-i studies have convinced [me]0-i that the regulation of climates and the breeding of new varieties at will from the old stock is a feasible thing . Indeed [I]0-i am convinced that it has been done before ; done in prehistoric times by now forgotten and unrecorded civilizations . Everywhere [I]0-i find hoary evidences of artificial manipulation of climates in bygone times . Take the glacial period . Was that produced by accident ? Not at all ; it was done for money . [I]0-i have a thousand proofs of it , and will some day reveal them . [I]0-i will confide to [you]1709-you an outline of [my]0-i idea . It is to utilize the spots on the sun — get control of them , [you]1709-you understand , and apply the stupendous energies which [they]1710-they wield to beneficent purposes in the reorganizing of [our]1711-our climates . At present [they]1710-they merely make trouble and do harm in the evoking of cyclones and other kinds of electric storms ; but once under humane and intelligent control this will cease and they will become a boon to [man]2562-man . [I]0-i have [my]0-i plan all mapped out , whereby [I]0-i hope and expect to acquire complete and perfect control of the sun - spots , also details of the method whereby [I]0-i shall employ the same commercially ; but [I]0-i will not venture to go into particulars before the patents shall have been issued . [I]0-i shall hope and expect to sell shop - rights to [the minor countries]1713-the minor countries at a reasonable figure and supply a good business article of climate to the great empires at special rates , together with fancy brands for coronations , battles and other great and particular occasions . There are billions of money in this enterprise , no expensive plant is required , and [I]0-i shall begin to realize in a few days — in a few weeks at furthest . [I]0-i shall stand ready to pay cash for [Siberia]17-siberia the moment it is delivered , and thus save [my]0-i honor and [my]0-i credit . [I]0-i am confident of this . [I]0-i would like [you]1709-you to provide a proper outfit and start north as soon as [I]0-i telegraph [you]1709-you , be it night or be it day . [I]0-i wish [you]1709-you to take up [all the country stretching away from [the north pole]1550-the north pole on all sides for many degrees south]1714-all the country stretching away from the north pole on all sides for many degrees south , and buy [Greenland]86-greenland and [Iceland]87-iceland at the best figure [you]1709-you can get now while they are cheap . It is [my]0-i intention to move one of the tropics up there and transfer [the frigid zone]1716-the frigid zone to [the equator]1717-the equator . [I]0-i will have the entire [Arctic Circle]88-arctic circle in the market as [a summer resort]1718-a summer resort next year , and will use the surplusage of the old climate , over and above what can be utilized on [the equator]1717-the equator , to reduce the temperature of [opposition resorts]1720-opposition resorts . But [I]0-i have said enough to give [you]1709-you an idea of the prodigious nature of [my]0-i scheme and the feasible and enormously profitable character of it . [I]0-i shall join [all [you]1709-you happy people in [England]11-england]1721-all you happy people in england as soon as [I]0-i shall have sold out some of [[my]0-i principal climates]1722-my principal climates and arranged with [the Czar]2262-the czar about [Siberia]17-siberia . Meantime , watch for a sign from [me]0-i . Eight days from now , [we]1724-we shall be wide asunder ; for [I]0-i shall be on [the border of [the Pacific]89-the pacific]1725-the border of the pacific , and [you]1709-you far out on [the Atlantic]66-the atlantic , approaching [England]11-england . That day , if [I]0-i am alive and [my]0-i sublime discovery is proved and established , [I]0-i will send [you]1709-you greeting , and [[my]0-i messenger]1726-my messenger shall deliver it where [you]1709-you are , in [the solitudes of [the sea]349-the sea]1727-the solitudes of the sea ; for [I]0-i will waft a vast sun - spot across the disk like drifting smoke , and [you]1709-you will know it for [my]0-i love - sign , and will say “ [Mulberry Sellers]110-rossmore throws [us]3305-us a kiss across [the universe]3306-the universe . ”[1738-us] APPENDIX . WEATHER FOR USE IN THIS BOOK . _ Selected from the Best Authorities . _ A brief though violent thunderstorm which had raged over [the city]776-the city was passing away ; but still , though the rain had ceased more than an hour before , wild piles of dark and coppery clouds , in which a fierce and rayless glow was laboring , gigantically overhung the grotesque and huddled vista of [dwarf houses]1730-dwarf houses , while in the distance , sheeting high over the low , misty confusion of [gables]1731-gables and chimneys , spread a pall of dead , leprous blue , suffused with blotches of dull , glistening yellow , and with black plague - spots of vapor floating and faint lightnings crinkling on its surface . Thunder , still muttering in the close and sultry air , kept [the scared dwellers in [the street]741-the street within , behind [their]1732-the scared dwellers in the street within , behind their closed shutters closed shutters]1732-the scared dwellers in the street within , behind their closed shutters ; and all deserted , cowed , dejected , squalid , like [poor , stupid , top - heavy things that had felt the wrath of the summer tempest]1734-poor , stupid , top - heavy things that had felt the wrath of the summer tempest , stood [the drenched structures on either side of the narrow and crooked way]1735-the drenched structures on either side of the narrow and crooked way , ghastly and picturesque , under the giant canopy . Rain dripped wretchedly in slow drops of melancholy sound from their projecting eaves upon the broken flagging , lay there in pools or trickled into the swollen drains , where the fallen torrent sullenly gurgled on its way to [the river]1736-the river . “ _ The Brazen Android._”—_W.[1738-us] [D. O’Connor]90-d. o’connor _ . The fiery mid - March sun a moment hung Above [the bleak Judean wilderness]1737-the bleak judean wilderness ; Then darkness swept upon [us]1738-us , and ’ t was night . “ _ Easter - Eve at [Kerak - Moab_.”—_Clinton[1738-us] Scollard]91-kerak - moab_.”—_clinton scollard _ . The quick - coming winter twilight was already at hand . Snow was again falling , sifting delicately down , incidentally as it were.—“_Felicia_.”—“_Fanny N. D. Murfree “[1743-his] _ . Merciful heavens ! [The whole west]1739-the whole west , from right to left , blazes up with a fierce light , and next instant [the earth]1900-the earth reels and quivers with the awful shock of ten thousand batteries of artillery . It is the signal for the Fury to spring — for a thousand demons to scream and shriek — for innumerable serpents of fire to writhe and light up the blackness . Now the rain falls — now the wind is let loose with a terrible shriek — now the lightning is so constant that the eyes burn , and the thunder - claps merge into an awful roar , as did the 800 cannon at [Gettysburg]92-gettysburg . Crash ! Crash ! Crash ! It is the cottonwood trees falling to [earth]434-earth . Shriek ! Shriek ! Shriek ! It is the Demon racing along [the plain]1742-the plain and uprooting even the blades of grass . Shock ! Shock ! Shock ! It is the Fury flinging [his]1743-his fiery bolts into the bosom of the earth.—“_The Demon and the Fury_.”—_M.[258-egbert craddock] Quad _ . Away up [the gorge]1744-the gorge [all diurnal fancies]1745-all diurnal fancies trooped into the wide liberties of endless luminous vistas of [azure sunlit mountains beneath the shining azure heavens]1746-azure sunlit mountains beneath the shining azure heavens . The sky , looking down in deep blue placidities , only here and there smote the water to azure emulations of [its]1747-its tint.—“_In the People ’s Country_.”—_Charles[259-alfred] [Egbert Craddock]258-egbert craddock _ . There was every indication of a dust - storm , though the sun still shone brilliantly . The hot wind had become wild and rampant . It was whipping up the sandy coating of [the plain]1742-the plain in every direction . High in the air were seen whirling spires and cones of sand — a curious effect against the deep - blue sky . Below , puffs of sand were breaking out of [the plain]1742-the plain in every direction , as though [the plain]1742-the plain were alive with invisible horsemen . These sandy cloudlets were instantly dissipated by the wind ; it was the larger clouds that were lifted whole into the air , and the larger clouds of sand were becoming more and more the rule . [Alfred]259-alfred ’s eye , quickly scanning the horizon , descried the roof of [[the boundary - rider]1751-the boundary - rider ’s hut]1752-the boundary - rider ’s hut still gleaming in the sunlight . [He]259-alfred remembered [the hut]1753-the hut well . [It]1753-the hut could not be farther than four miles , if as much as that , from this point of the track . [He]259-alfred also knew these dust - storms of old ; [Bindarra]93-bindarra was notorious for them : Without thinking twice , [Alfred]259-alfred put spurs to [his]259-alfred horse and headed for [the hut]1753-the hut . Before [he]259-alfred had ridden half the distance the detached clouds of sand banded together in one dense whirlwind , and it was only owing to [his]259-alfred horse ’s instinct that [he]259-alfred did not ride wide of [the hut]1753-the hut altogether ; for during the last half - mile [he]259-alfred never saw [the hut]1753-the hut , until [its]1753-the hut outline loomed suddenly over [his]259-alfred horse ’s ears ; and by then the sun was invisible.—“_A Bride from [the Bush]94-the bush _ . ”[None-None] It rained forty days and forty nights.—_Genesis _ . * * *
